reviewText:
My steam account only shows 22 hours on this game as I purchased this digital copy only recently so I could play coop with my six-year-old son.  I’ve played this, the 2011, and the 2009 versions for many countless hours.

As background, I have a graduate degree in agriculture economics and have spent a good portion of my life farming.  By all accounts, I should dislike this game:

* the controls are clunky
* the physics are often aggravating
* the particle flow/dust and other graphical elements are a throwback to 1990’s 3D engines
* the ‘farming’ elements are incredibly simplistic and the economics are silly.

And yet there is something oddly cathartic and relaxing about this game that keeps me coming back for more day after day.

I derive the most enjoyment from utilizing some of the many modifications to stretch this game to its limits.  The most important is Courseplay, which allows me to automate most of the tasks and play a managerial role, even though the game it technically a driving simulator.  I also enjoy user-submitted maps, such as Paradise 2013, which are set up for larger operations and automated farming.

Even though I wish the developers would license a better game engine so that the physics, rendering, and particle flow are more realistic, as well as include an 'advanced' mode that actually adjusts growth conditions and incorporates specific pests/weeds that I have to control, I can’t help but think that I’ll keep playing this game for a long time to come.

reviewText:
This is surprisingly good for something that doesn't even try to hide the fact it's a farming simulator. That said, of course it still *is* a farming simulator, so you *will* be doing some things that are a little more tedious than you'd expect from a typical game. For example, there's no denying that a large part of farm work is driving up and down a field at slow speed, so you will be doing some of that. At the same time you don't have most of the sources of excitement that other open world games have, you're doing honest work (except if you're stealing golf carts, which is possible and apparently nobody cares) so you're not going to be in any police chases or shootouts. The game does a very good job at simulating a farm. You start out with some money, machinery, a loan, and a field (depending on difficulty) and manage the operation from there on. You tend your fields, buy machines, buy more fields, perhaps some animals, and so on, and the level of detail is mostly pretty good. All this takes place in a completely open world, and while you can't buy any cars unless you install mods, there's a very large selection of tractors and other equipment that you can drive around. The nice thing is that equipment generally works like you'd expect it to work: Trailers can be attached to tractors, or in some cases to other trailers, making trains; then you drive them over a grate and press a key to unload your grains, which will happen in a way specific to the type of trailer you're using. Front loaders can pick up things and carry them around, sowers sow, sprayers spray, additional tanks attached to the front of your tractor provide more fertilizer for the sprayer attached to its rear, balers pick up straw and make bales, which you can then pick up with a front loader or another machine that stacks them. Cows produce manure, which you can use to fertilize your fields if you choose to do so, and so forth.

The game does try to alleviate some of the tedium by letting you hire help for some of the repetitive driving tasks. For example, plowing, cultivating, sowing, fertilizing, spraying, and harvesting can all be done by a computer controlled clone of you. This is implemented very nicely, you just drive the machine to the starting point and press H and it'll start doing what you'd expect it to do. For example, a combine harvester will start slowly harvesting your field, driving up and down, and eventually stop when it's full. Then you can pull up next to it with a trailer and the computer help will extend the combine's pipe and unload the harvest into your trailer and continue. Similarly if you drive next to it while it's harvesting, it'll transfer the harvest to your trailer as you go. This makes it very easy to do some of the typical farming tasks that normally require more than one person. It also adds an aspect of time management to the game when you have multiple computer controlled helpers working your fields and need to jump around between them to support them.

You also don't have to wait for your plants to grow. There are three settings to control how fast plants grow, and separately you can also speed up time by 120x. Machines only work at one fixed pace, though.

The farming aspect of this game includes various types of grains, potatoes, beets, as well as cattle (for dairy), sheep (for wool), and chicken (for eggs). Additionally, you can buy green houses that you can freely place on the map to grow things such as herbs or tomatoes, and you can buy bee houses that'll produce honey.

In addition to typical farming tasks, there also are some half arsed missions (basically two types: one requires you to pick up something with a front loader, another requires you to mow strangely rectangular areas where grass suddenly appeared on the golf course). You can also buy solar panels and wind energy converters, which will provide a nice consistent stream of extra income (they're a little too good).

I'm rating this game a 9 out of 10 because it's a good farming simulator with a very nice open world and very detailed equipment. But as I stated above, it's still a farming simulator, and not an action game, and I would not necessarily expect it to appeal to the same audience as other open world games.

Now that the new Farming Simulator 15 has come out, its high time to write down my personal thoughts of 2013 Titanium.
This is a game sim about running a modern farm. You get 2 maps to start with, Hagenstedt and Westbridge Hills. The game started off with Hagenstedt, but more content and Westbridge Hills was added later in the Titanium upgrade.
So what do you do at your farm?
You grow crops, manage ure animals and do missions to put it simply.
The crops that you can grow are: Wheat, Barley, Canola, Sugar Beets and Potatoes.
The animals you can have are: Cows, Sheep and Chickens.
There is also two type of missions you can do: Transport Missions and Mowing.
You can freely choose how you play the game, and can freely roam on the map, doing what you like. If you only wanna grow crops, for example, thats just fine.

Pros:
- The free playstyle, doing what you want, when you want.
- Multiplayer. This game is made for it, you can have tons of fun with ure friends working together on the farm.
- Loads of equipment. From plows to harvesters.
- Easy to learn and get into.
- Literally TONS of mods to further enhance your gameplay!

Cons:
I really cant say bad things about the game, but no game is perfect.
- The handling of some machines are wonky and hard to control (but you get used to it.)
- Easy to get stuck in fences/rocks and stupid Ai cars. (Fortunately there is a reset function for ure equipment if it flips over or get stuck.)
- It sometimes feels like your alone in a empty world just driving your machines in single player. There is Ai cars and people, but still feels empty. (Multiplayer fixes that.)

My personal Thoughts:
This is one of my favorite types of sim games. The playstyle is relaxed and easy. Might be a bit stressful at harvest time, but other than that, its really a great game. The game flows well, atleast in single player. Lag issues and small freezes can occur in multplayer, but thats not the game´s fault. I had some great fun farming with my friends. Its a perfect co-op game to work at your farm and earn cash for new machinery and expanding your farm.
The game has plenty of machines and equipment to choose from and isnt that enough, there is a great mod community that offers tons of mods of all sorts from new maps and new equipment to gameplay mechanics.

This is a great game if u like farming sim games. The new one is out, but i recommend to get this new classic" too."

There's quite a few things that can be said about Farming Simulator 2013. I'd say it is aimed at a specific audience for a start. Some may find the gameplay potentially mind-numbing due to the whole repetitiveness with no action, but personally I find it's not too bad to play, because in some points you can also hire workers if you find it too stretching. Essentially: Start with a little bit of money and some vehicles. Plant stuff, harvest, sell, repeat and get more income so that you're able to upgrade your vehicles, equipment and buy more land to maximise your profit. Pretty much an endless cycle until you have the best equipment and vehicles.
The graphics aren't particularly good, but if you're someone that isn't bothered by that - You'll be right.

The physics are pretty weird, but that's fine because they're pretty funny to play with. The game can also be customised to a certain degree with a large variety of community maps and vehicles that can be downloaded in.
Once again, I say that this game is surely not for everyone, but it's not bad if you don't mind the straight forward farming concept with partial monetary and banking section involved.

In final, I'd say pick this up on a sale if you like the look of it. What you see from gameplay and trailers are essentially what you get. You're in charge of your own wallet here.

An interesting insight in to the mundanity (not sure if that's a word!) of farming. Essentially, this game focuses on all the things that bored me when I was a farmer years ago. Sorry, I just found this game intensely dull, it's not overly complex. Plant, harvest, plow, prepare. When you've repeated that, buy some more fields and do it again.

reviewText:
It's Minecraft without the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It's Farmville without the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.
It's a deconstruction of the whole RPG genre. The only castle you have is your home, the only quests are the future.
Yes, it's aggravating at first. You search desperately for the bandits and the dragons and pretty princesses. You watch videos and expect extreme dubstep drops from space.
But, spoiler alert, you won't miss such trivialities. The game wakes you up from such petty tropes. What good is a princess with 2 lines of text? Or a recurring enemy who appears hundreds of times in the course of walking from 1 town to another?
Farming Simulator 2013 doesn't try lying to you, not once. The game offers you quests every so often, to mow a lawn or haul a crate across the lush, bountiful countryside. A simple diversion to earn a simple amount of cash while your farm hands do the repetitive tasks.
And then oh god yes, the multiplayer. Sublime bliss, shared amongst your friends.

reviewText:
Introduction
Farming Simulator is by far the best farming simulation franchise out there and this edition is no exception. It has much more equipment and a better appearance.  Many may know it for its glitchy physics but in truth this is the most realistic farming simulator on steam and on the gaming market. If you are interested in the world of agriculture or just love machines then this is definitely the game for you.

Gameplay
Farming Simulator 2013 is, as i say again, by far the best farming simulator out there to date. With the expection of very bouncy and unrealistic physics, it is the most realistic agricultural simulator that you can find. The graphics could do with an upgrade to compete with other simulation games such as Euro Truck Simulator 2 but none the less the equipment you can buy is still fairly detailed.

When you first jump into the game you are given a very large, yet abandoned farm. You are given a few older tractors to start off with and some basic implements to put on the back. Things start off slow but it doesn't take long before you can be running a highly profitable business. In the begining you are expected to work the fields by planting grain crops such as wheat, barley or canola. The smallest leap into new areas of farming is to simply buy yourself a mower and plant grass instead. As you get further into the game you can explore new areas of farming from turning silage into biogas to growing potatoes and harvesting them with some colossal machinery.

Farming Simulator 2013 has a large variety of real life tractors, implements and other agricultural equipment which look fairly good. If you feel that this selection is not large enough for you and you need more equipment then there is a large and very active modding community for this game with most mods being very simple to install. You can find some of the best mods here[www.farming-simulator.com] on GIANTS own website.

Conclusion
Farming Simulator is very addictive. Before long you will be wracking up many hours of gameplay. The quantity of areas to explore can lead you into hundreds of hours of gaming pleasure and when you've explored all of that there's still the modding community to rely on. If you like farming or big machines i can almost guarentee that you'll love this game.

You won't find a better time to try a new game type than the Steam Summer Sale.  That was my justification for buying this one; it's super cheap, and you should be willing to try anything at least once, with an open mind.

How is this game?  Let me give you an elaborate analogy: if gaming is like eating, then your 60-hour RPGs are the heavy turkey dinner.  FPSs are like the coffee afterward.  Indie platformers are the sugary deserts, 2D fighters are the alternate pasta entree, and MOBAs are the pizza the loud guys upstairs are having.

THIS game is like the nap you have after eating too much.  The caffeine buzz has time to wear off, you feel a little less heavy because you've digested that turkey, and you're nice and relaxed because all your dinner guests have gone home.  The upstairs neighbors have gone to a sports bar to watch the game.

This game is like taking a nap with your eyes open.  The first 2 stages of the tutorial were, collectively, a nice 32-minute nap.

reviewText:
17 hours of my life I'll never get back, although still better than that time I woke up in a trough in Dundee wearing urinal cake glasses. You know your life has taken a turn for the worse when you're harvesting crops on a Friday night.

This could honestly be an enjoyable game if they fixed the following issues:

- Worker AI is pretty bad. If they face an obstruction of any sort such as a tree, other equipment or even another worker, they will just idle there and you end up still paying them
- Driving to and from the market to sell your harvest can't be automated, resulting in an enjoyable trip through empty towns on a 5mph tractor
- You can't run over people because everyone are just ghosts. Is this a farming sim or Scooby Doo?
- Some in-game music would be lovely. I suggest the Wurzels or Rednex for next year's iteration
- You can buy beehives, chickens etc. to get some regular income but no options for brewing moonshine or selling your family
- I know it's meant to be a simulator, but buggering up things by driving too fast is not fun. Either cap the max speed so you don't have to accelerate for 3 seconds then stop pressing W for a while, or just remove this altogether so equipment doesn't fall off your vehicle etc.

You won't find a better time to try a new game type than the Steam Summer Sale.  That was my justification for buying this one; it's super cheap, and you should be willing to try anything at least once, with an open mind.

Indie platformers are the sugary deserts, 2D fighters are the alternate pasta entree, and MOBAs are the pizza the loud guys upstairs are having.

THIS game is like the nap you have after eating too much.  The caffeine buzz has time to wear off, you feel a little less heavy because you've digested that turkey, and you're nice and relaxed because all your dinner guests have gone home.  The upstairs neighbors have gone to a sports bar to watch the game.

This game is like taking a nap with your eyes open.  The first 2 stages of the tutorial were, collectively, a nice 32-minute nap.

reviewText:
Summary: A game for those who don't care whether their farm has aliens they need to fight off, or NPCs they can romance. This game doesn't have that. It has farming equipment and a great environment for people looking for a relaxing evening or a great co-operative experience with friends who enjoy simulated farming with heavy equipment.

Hours of fun: *Varies - If you like simulators then it may well be infinite
Suggested Retail Value: $20
Graphics: 7/10
Voice-acting: NA - No voice-acting
Music/SFX: NA - Calm music on menus only
Uniqueness: 5/10
First Play-through Experience: 8/10
Replay Value: 9/10

If you have any love for simulated farming then I doubt you would regret paying up to $20 for the full version. I was introduced to the game through a friend who had put in 100s of hours and just convinced me to give it a try so I could experience what he loved so much about it. I didn't expect it to be this much fun, but it's a blast on co-op play.
After a stressful day, I can sit back and relax and handle issues as they rise. Choosing to pace myself in the game by switching it to real-time and literally doing needed chores then watching the beautiful sunset or... whatever.
Then, when I'm feeling ambitious, we both hop into our private server and divy up the tasks at hand, co-operating in beautiful harmony to bring our farm ever closer to being a mega-success.
It's hard to describe how it feels to grow a farm from humble beginnings with one small field to a booming business with dozens of fields, 1000s of tons of equipment, and a ranch boasting hundreds of animals, but I highly recommend sharing it with friends.
To help with that, the game has an incredible community. Whether you're looking to see the mods that are available, wanting to create your own, looking for a buddy to chat with while you drive the harvesters, or wanting to join a sever with dozens of players trying to achieve a shared farm (even splitting up the tasks, creating jobs, dolling out wages, the whole deal!) the truth is you'll find it all here.
I say this about few games (Skyrim readily comes to mind) but FS 2013 feels less like a game and more like a world you visit for as long as you like. Highly recommended if the above sounds interesting to you.

reviewText:
Ok, just one more crop before I go to bed....

♥♥♥♥, it's 6am.

People laugh and scoff at the idea of Farming Simulator, but you can't deny the 90%+ positive reviews. That's what ultimately led me to give it a try (and it was $4 on sale). This game is really fun, even if you're mainly chugging through to get the achievements like I did at first. Then you realize this is a really great sim game.

It's a steeper learning curve than most, but with guides you can adjust easily. The scope is a little overwhelming at first too, but it certainly takes patience (just like real crops?). Gameplay is addicting and fun. Haven't tried MP, but looks like it's almost essential to keep from going mad (there's a LOT to do and keep tabs on).

Graphics aren't bad, and no real bugs from what I've encountered so far. A solid game. Mod community is big, and plenty to download.

If you like any kind of city building or other sim games you have to give this one a go.

8/10

+Gameplay is fun and solid
+Graphics on par for a non AAA title in '13
+Modding community
+DLCs are fun but not required to enjoy the full game

-Clunky interface
-Tutorial only covers machine operation
-Physics not always consistent

reviewText:
OK... where to begin... Let's dive straight in, shall we?

PROS:

- It's cheap! Given there's a newer version out, this is a bargain. (Of course, why you'd even CONSIDER buying a new version is beyond me, once is truly, SURELY enough...)
- It provides a very clear insight into the riveting, high octane world of farming!
- lots of vehicles, accessories, things to load, unload, fill, plough etc (if that's your bag...)

CONS:
- I wanted to die while I played this...
- It's a simulator about farming - and yep, you guessed it, it's 'somewhat' realistic. That means it's so frightfully boring and dull you'll have trouble stopping your brain from exploding.
- There are in excess of 3000 people who own this game who gave it the thumbs up... Why is that a CON? Well... let's put it this way, the type of people who'd most likely give this a thumbs up probably like watching grass grow, and can't get enough of farming so they turn to a simulator to continue the experience into the evening. I'm shocked. Seriously I am.

SUMMARY: It's not that the game is terrible. In fact, you could very reasonably argue that in playing a farming simulator, you need to set your expectations lower than a crack ho' turning tricks with Jack the Ripper. But here's the thing - even knowing it's a farming simulator, it still was so awfully dull, so painfully boring that I can't believe I played as long as I did.

I mowed some grass at a golf course, I drove a tractor with a trailor perfectly lined up next to a harvester to catch wheat, then dumped said wheat in a grain silo, I took a load of peanuts to a place so they could attract a runaway elephant back (yep, you heard me right), i sold a tractor, I ploughed a field. Then I realised I was SPENDING MINUTES OF MY LIFE, JUST WASTING AWAY DOING THIS!!!!

The tutorial was mildly amusing for 5 minutes, then the game just continues the awful, mind-sapping exercise. Oh man, how this game will sap your very soul!

I love this game and I hate it. I love sims and farming and all that stuff that's boring, and this does all that. The only problem with it is the physics. It's like farming on Mars. Carrying a pallet on your forklift and hit a bump, have fun chasing it down and spending the next 5 minutes lining your forks back up just right to load it up and have it sailing off into oblivion the next bump you hit. Get your sheep going, finally get a few pallets of wool together and loaded on the trailer? Make sure not to turn that trailer because, as we all know, any sort of turn sends your load flying off. Accidentally hit Q on your harvester? Better bring your forklift over to try to flip your implement for the next 10 minutes.

Accidentally put grass in your hopper instead of grains, have fun tilling that field for the next half hour and never getting it quite right.

It's just bad. It could be a great game but it just isn't. Models are great, the towns are OK, gameplay is decent aside from the just terrible physics. Accidentally hitting one key will cost you 20 minutes of frustration. If you buy this game I suggest you save often because it's better to load 10 minutes back than try to recover from the slightest mistake.

What can I say? It's a farming simulator. It has great graphics, good vehicle choice, and several methods to aquire crops, funds, and other things.

It also has great modding support, adding even more vehicles and mechanics into the game. Having multiplayer is also a nice touch.

With the vanilla game, however, it has its limitations. Aside from 'make money', there are no goals and no directions. For me, I love FS 2013.  I grew up on a farm, I went to an Ag school for pre-vet.  So, it's a fun game, although I don't really consider it a game.  It's a simulator....like any other sim, except with this one, you get to be farmer John.  This sim is a great learning tool.  I play with my kids.  I teach them the value and importance of saving and working.  I start each with 100,000 dollars.  I told them thats all the money they get, and teach them about saving...in this case for needed equipment.   It's actually perfect for this kind of thing.

From a personal standpoint, I'd like to see a few changes.  Since there is now an American farm, it'd be nice to see the weather in degrees, instead of celsius.  I know most probably use Centigrade, however, it'd at least be nice to be able to toggle from one or the other.  Also, since you don't have the means at the start, it'd be nice to be able to buy hay and straw for feeding purposes.  You can buy animals and other placeable buildings, so doing this would enhance the simulation.   Additionally, for the American farm, putting the fields in acres instead of hectares would be a nice change as well.   Lastly, it'd be nice to see the seasons change for a more realistic planting experience.  Example, corn in spring/summer, wheat in winter.  Perhaps color coding the calendar with fall/winter/summer would be a good way to accomplish this.
